snippet: The Supreme Court should hear a Maryland case that raises important questions about whether the collection of DNA samples from people arrested but not yet convicted violates the Fourth Amendment.
abstract: Editorial urges the Supreme Court to take up a case from Maryland in which a court held that collection of DNA samples from people who have been arrested but not convicted is a violation of the Fourth Amendment; contends that the court should hear the case because the privacy issues raised are significant and there is disagreement among state and federal courts that have considered the question.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court should hear a Maryland case that raises important questions about whether the collection of DNA samples from people arrested but not yet convicted violates the Fourth Amendment.
